natural problem: What is the remainder when $301^4$ is divided by 10,000?
natural solution: By the Binomial Theorem, we have  \begin{align} 301^4 &= (3(100) + 1)^4\\ &= \binom40 \cdot 3^4 \cdot 100^4 \cdot 1^0 + \binom41 \cdot 3^3 \cdot 100^3 \cdot 1^1 \\ &\qquad\qquad+ \binom42 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 100^2 \cdot 1^2+ \binom43 \cdot 3^1 \cdot 100^1 \cdot 1^3 \\

&\qquad\qquad+ \binom44 \cdot 3^0 \cdot 100^0 \cdot 1^4. \end{align} All but the last two terms are divisible by $10000=100^2$, so we only have to consider the remainder when the last two terms are divided by 10,000.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 301 ^ 4"
shows  "n mod 10000 = 1201"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $301^4$ is divided by 10,000? The final Answer is 1201
 ### Proof
 By the Binomial Theorem, we have  \begin{align} 301^4 &= (3(100) + 1)^4\\ &= \binom40 \cdot 3^4 \cdot 100^4 \cdot 1^0 + \binom41 \cdot 3^3 \cdot 100^3 \cdot 1^1 \\ &\qquad\qquad+ \binom42 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 100^2 \cdot 1^2+ \binom43 \cdot 3^1 \cdot 100^1 \cdot 1^3 \\
 &\qquad\qquad+ \binom44 \cdot 3^0 \cdot 100^0 \cdot 1^4. \end{align} All but the last two terms are divisible by $10000=100^2$, so we only have to consider the remainder when the last two terms are divided by 10,000.
 The last two terms are  \begin{align} \binom43 &\cdot 3^1 \cdot 100^1 \cdot 1^3 + \binom44 \cdot 3^0 \cdot 100^0 \cdot 1^4\\ &= 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 100 \cdot 1 + 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1\\ & = 1200 + 1 = \boxed{1201}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 301 ^ 4"
shows  "n mod 10000 = 1201"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the last four digits of $301^4$. The final answer is 1201.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 301 ^ 4"
and h1 : "b = 10000"
and h2 : "a mod b = c"
shows  "c = 1201"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $301^4$ is divided by 10,000? The final Answer is 1201
 ### Proof
 By the Binomial Theorem, we have  \begin{align} 301^4 &= (3(100) + 1)^4\\ &= \binom40 \cdot 3^4 \cdot 100^4 \cdot 1^0 + \binom41 \cdot 3^3 \cdot 100^3 \cdot 1^1 \\ &\qquad\qquad+ \binom42 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 100^2 \cdot 1^2+ \binom43 \cdot 3^1 \cdot 100^1 \cdot 1^3 \\
 &\qquad\qquad+ \binom44 \cdot 3^0 \cdot 100^0 \cdot 1^4. \end{align} All but the last two terms are divisible by $10000=100^2$, so we only have to consider the remainder when the last two terms are divided by 10,000.
 The last two terms are  \begin{align} \binom43 &\cdot 3^1 \cdot 100^1 \cdot 1^3 + \binom44 \cdot 3^0 \cdot 100^0 \cdot 1^4\\ &= 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 100 \cdot 1 + 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1\\ & = 1200 + 1 = \boxed{1201}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 301 ^ 4"
and h1 : "b = 10000"
and h2 : "a mod b = c"
shows  "c = 1201"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Calculate the remainder when $301^4$ is divided by 10,000. The final answer is 1,201.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 301 ^ 4"
and h1 : "b = 10000"
and h2 : "\<exists> q. a = b * q + c \<and> c < b"
shows  "c = 1201"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $301^4$ is divided by 10,000? The final Answer is 1201
 ### Proof
 By the Binomial Theorem, we have  \begin{align} 301^4 &= (3(100) + 1)^4\\ &= \binom40 \cdot 3^4 \cdot 100^4 \cdot 1^0 + \binom41 \cdot 3^3 \cdot 100^3 \cdot 1^1 \\ &\qquad\qquad+ \binom42 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 100^2 \cdot 1^2+ \binom43 \cdot 3^1 \cdot 100^1 \cdot 1^3 \\
 &\qquad\qquad+ \binom44 \cdot 3^0 \cdot 100^0 \cdot 1^4. \end{align} All but the last two terms are divisible by $10000=100^2$, so we only have to consider the remainder when the last two terms are divided by 10,000.
 The last two terms are  \begin{align} \binom43 &\cdot 3^1 \cdot 100^1 \cdot 1^3 + \binom44 \cdot 3^0 \cdot 100^0 \cdot 1^4\\ &= 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 100 \cdot 1 + 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1\\ & = 1200 + 1 = \boxed{1201}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 301 ^ 4"
and h1 : "b = 10000"
and h2 : "\<exists> q. a = b * q + c \<and> c < b"
shows  "c = 1201"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the remainder when $301^4$ is divided by $10,000$. The final answer is $1,201$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x n :: nat
assumes h0 : "x = 301"
and h1 : "n = 4"
shows  "x ^ n mod 10000 = 1201"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $301^4$ is divided by 10,000? The final Answer is 1201
 ### Proof
 By the Binomial Theorem, we have  \begin{align} 301^4 &= (3(100) + 1)^4\\ &= \binom40 \cdot 3^4 \cdot 100^4 \cdot 1^0 + \binom41 \cdot 3^3 \cdot 100^3 \cdot 1^1 \\ &\qquad\qquad+ \binom42 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 100^2 \cdot 1^2+ \binom43 \cdot 3^1 \cdot 100^1 \cdot 1^3 \\
 &\qquad\qquad+ \binom44 \cdot 3^0 \cdot 100^0 \cdot 1^4. \end{align} All but the last two terms are divisible by $10000=100^2$, so we only have to consider the remainder when the last two terms are divided by 10,000.
 The last two terms are  \begin{align} \binom43 &\cdot 3^1 \cdot 100^1 \cdot 1^3 + \binom44 \cdot 3^0 \cdot 100^0 \cdot 1^4\\ &= 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 100 \cdot 1 + 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1\\ & = 1200 + 1 = \boxed{1201}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x n :: nat
assumes h0 : "x = 301"
and h1 : "n = 4"
shows  "x ^ n mod 10000 = 1201"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: What is the remainder when $301^4$ is divided by $10,000$? The final answer is $1201$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and Q R :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x^4"
and h1 : "301^4 div 10000 = Q"
and h2 : "301^4 mod 10000 = R"
shows  "R = 1201"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $301^4$ is divided by 10,000? The final Answer is 1201
 ### Proof
 By the Binomial Theorem, we have  \begin{align} 301^4 &= (3(100) + 1)^4\\ &= \binom40 \cdot 3^4 \cdot 100^4 \cdot 1^0 + \binom41 \cdot 3^3 \cdot 100^3 \cdot 1^1 \\ &\qquad\qquad+ \binom42 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 100^2 \cdot 1^2+ \binom43 \cdot 3^1 \cdot 100^1 \cdot 1^3 \\
 &\qquad\qquad+ \binom44 \cdot 3^0 \cdot 100^0 \cdot 1^4. \end{align} All but the last two terms are divisible by $10000=100^2$, so we only have to consider the remainder when the last two terms are divided by 10,000.
 The last two terms are  \begin{align} \binom43 &\cdot 3^1 \cdot 100^1 \cdot 1^3 + \binom44 \cdot 3^0 \cdot 100^0 \cdot 1^4\\ &= 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 100 \cdot 1 + 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1\\ & = 1200 + 1 = \boxed{1201}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and Q R :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x^4"
and h1 : "301^4 div 10000 = Q"
and h2 : "301^4 mod 10000 = R"
shows  "R = 1201"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If $P(x) = x^4$, find the last four digits of $301^4$. The final answer is $1201$.
